title: Arzoo Lakhnavi
text:
Arzoo Lakhnavi (born Syed Anwar Hussain; 16 February 1873 17 Apr 1951), also known by the honorary title <a href="Allamah">Allamah</a> Arzoo Lakhnavi, was an <a href="Urdu">Urdu</a> poet and lyricist. He wrote almost in every genre of <a href="Urdu%20poetry">Urdu poetry</a> such as <a href="marsiya">marsiya</a>, <a href="qasida">qasida</a>, <a href="Mathnawi%20%28poetic%20form%29">mathnawi</a>, <a href="ruba%CA%BFi">rubaʿi</a>, <a href="na%CA%BDat">naʽat</a>, <a href="chronogram">chronogram</a> inscriptions and particularly <a href="gazal">gazal</a>s and lyrics throughout his life, and by the latter wrote radio plays and scripts for several uncertain Urdu films.
He was born to a poet Mir Zakir Hussain 'Yas' as Syed Anwar Hussain around 16 February 1873 in <a href="North-Western%20Provinces">North-Western Provinces</a>, <a href="British%20Raj">British India</a> (in modern-day <a href="Lucknow">Lucknow</a>, India). He was the elder brother of an Urdu poet, Mir Yusuf Hussain 'Qayas'.
Biography.
He was associated with poetry during his school days. He was taught by <a href="Jalal%20Lakhnavi">Jalal Lakhnavi</a>, an Urdu poet. He received his <a href="Primary%20education">initially schooling</a> at his home and later went to Lucknow where he studied <a href="Persian%20language">Persian</a> and <a href="Arabic%20language">Arabic language</a>s. He wrote his first marsiya at an apparent age of twelve. In 1942, he went to <a href="Bombay">Bombay</a> where he established his association with <a href="Bollywood">Hindi film industry</a>. Following the <a href="Partition%20of%20India">partition</a>, he later <a href="Muhajir%20%28Urdu-speaking%20people%29">migrated to Pakistan</a> where he remained associated with the <a href="Radio%20Pakistan">Radio Pakistan</a> in Karachi. He wrote poetry in various forms, however he earned his recognition with gazals. His uncertain authorship includes seven <a href="Diwan%20%28poetry%29">diwan</a>s such as "Fughan-e-Arzoo", "Jahan-e-Arzoo" and "Nishan-e-Arzoo" consisting twenty-five thousand gazals. He earned "Allamah" title primarily for gazal writings. Most of his work, particularly gazals revolves around <a href="Romance%20%28love%29">romance</a>. He wrote lyrics for Hindi films such as "Karoon Kya Aas", "Dushman", "Street Singer" among others. He also wrote a book titled "Sureeli Bansuri" in <a href="Hindustani%20language">Hindustani language</a>.
He died on 17 April 1951 in <a href="Karachi">Karachi</a>, Pakistan.
